title: RNAi: Slicing, dicing and serving your cells - Alex Dainis

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of RNA in the cell, as described in the kitchen analogy?

options.label: B
options.text: To direct amino acids to their targets

options.label: C
options.text: To act as a messenger between the DNA (cookbook) and the ribosome (countertop)

options.label: D
options.text: To take part in RNA interference (RNAi)

multiple-choice.question: What is RNA interference (RNAi), and what is its purpose in the cell?

options.label: A
options.text: RNAi is a process that helps create DNA, and its purpose is to produce more protein.

options.label: B
options.text: RNAi is a process that helps destroy RNA injected into the cell by an attacking virus, and its purpose is to prevent protein expression.

options.label: C
options.text: RNAi is a process that helps direct amino acids to their targets, and its purpose is to create more protein.

options.label: D
options.text: RNAi is a process that helps create mRNA, and its purpose is to produce more protein.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the protein dicer in the RNAi process?

options.label: B
options.text: To chop up long, double-stranded RNA molecules into short snippets

options.label: D
options.text: To destroy RNA injected into the cell by an attacking virus

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the RISC (RNA Silencing Complex) in the RNAi process?

options.label: B
options.text: To chop up long, double-stranded RNA molecules into short snippets

options.label: C
options.text: To target matching mRNA and slice it up

options.label: D
options.text: To destroy RNA injected into the cell by an attacking virus

multiple-choice.question: How was the process of RNAi first discovered?

options.label: A
options.text: Through experiments with C. elegans worms

multiple-choice.question: What was the unexpected result of introducing a pigment-producing gene into petunias?

options.label: A
options.text: The flowers produced more pigment and became darker

options.label: B
options.text: The flowers produced less pigment and became lighter

options.label: C
options.text: The flowers produced white patches and no pigment at all

options.label: D
options.text: The flowers produced no change in pigment

multiple-choice.question: How can RNAi be used to understand the function of a specific gene?

options.label: A
options.text: By introducing an RNAi construct for that gene and observing the effect

options.label: B
options.text: By creating a mutation in the gene and observing the effect

options.label: C
options.text: By deleting the gene and observing the effect

options.label: D
options.text: By overexpressing the gene and observing the effect

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential therapeutic application of RNAi?

options.label: A
options.text: Treating cancer by targeting RNA in tumor cells

options.label: B
options.text: Treating genetic disorders by introducing healthy copies of a gene

options.label: C
options.text: Treating viral infections by targeting viral RNA

options.label: D
options.text: Treating bacterial infections by targeting bacterial RNA

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the RISC complex slicing up mRNA?

options.label: A
options.text: The mRNA is translated into protein

options.label: B
options.text: The mRNA is degraded and not translated into protein

options.label: C
options.text: The mRNA is modified and translated into a different protein

options.label: D
options.text: The mRNA is stored for later translation

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall effect of RNAi on gene expression?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases gene expression by creating more mRNA

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases gene expression by degrading mRNA

options.label: C
options.text: It modifies gene expression by changing the sequence of mRNA

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on gene expression

options.text: It is a joke about people who understand mathematics.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a joke about people who don't understand technology.

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of the number 10 in base 3?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 in base b equals 2 in base 10.

options.label: B
options.text: 10 in base b equals b in base 10.

options.label: C
options.text: 10 in base b equals 10 in base 10.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: Why do we have to wear sunscreen? - Kevin P. Boyd

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of sunscreen?

options.label: B
options.text: To shield the body from the Sun's ultraviolet rays

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a type of ultraviolet ray that causes the skin to burn?

options.label: A
options.text: The protection provided from UVA rays

options.label: B
options.text: The protection provided from UVB rays

options.label: C
options.text: The protection provided from both UVA and UVB rays

options.label: D
options.text: The protection provided from skin cancer

multiple-choice.question: Why should children under the age of six months have almost no sun exposure?

options.label: A
options.text: Because their skin is too sensitive

options.label: B
options.text: Because their protective mechanisms are not fully functioning

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are more prone to skin cancer

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more likely to develop allergic reactions

multiple-choice.question: What is the leading cause of premature aging, along with cigarette smoking?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the sunscreen loses its effectiveness over time

options.label: B
options.text: Because the skin becomes more sensitive to the Sun's rays

options.label: C
options.text: Because the sunscreen is washed off by water or sweat

options.label: D
options.text: Because the skin needs more protection from UVA rays

multiple-choice.question: What should you look for when choosing a sunscreen?

options.label: A
options.text: Broad spectra, SPF of at least 15, and water-resistant

options.label: B
options.text: Broad spectra, SPF of at least 30, and water-resistant

options.label: C
options.text: Narrow spectra, SPF of at least 30, and water-resistant

options.label: D
options.text: Broad spectra, SPF of at least 50, and non-water-resistant

multiple-choice.question: Why is it recommended to use a light moisturizer with SPF 30 for daily use?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it provides adequate protection from UVA and UVB rays

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is more effective than a broad-spectrum sunscreen

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is less likely to cause allergic reactions

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is more convenient to apply than a separate sunscreen

title: The science of macaroni salad: What's in a mixture? - Josh Kurz

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process of combining two or more things together without changing their chemical identity?
What type of mixture is formed when particles of one thing are suspended in another, like muddy water or runny mustard?
What is an example of a solution, where the molecules of one substance are blended with molecules of another?
What type of mixture is formed when two materials that don't dissolve are combined, and the particles are made so small that they can't separate?
What is the substance called that helps bind oil and water together to form mayonnaise?
What is an example of a colloid, where small globs of oil are combined with small droplets of water?
What happens when you break down vegetables into smaller and smaller parts?

options.label: A
options.text: You get a mixture of different substances

options.label: B
options.text: You get a solution of molecules

options.label: C
options.text: You get thousands of complex organic molecules

options.label: D
options.text: You get a suspension of particles

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process of breaking down molecules into smaller parts, which requires breaking chemical bonds?
What is an example of a substance that is made up of thousands of complex organic molecules?
What is the result of unmixing all the solutions, colloids, suspensions, and vegetables in a mixture like macaroni salad?

options.label: D
options.text: A whole bunch of molecules that remain chemically the same
